en.washProduce_item_1: Wash your hands for 20 seconds with warm water and soap before and after preparing fresh produce.
en.washProduce_item_2: If damage or bruising occurs before eating or handling, cut away the damaged or bruised areas before preparing or eating.
en.washProduce_item_3: Rinse produce BEFORE you peel it, so dirt and bacteria aren’t transferred from the knife onto the fruit or vegetable.
en.washProduce_item_4: Gently rub produce while holding under plain running water. There’s no need to use soap or a produce wash.
en.washProduce_item_5: Use a clean vegetable brush to scrub firm produce, such as melons and cucumbers.
en.washProduce_item_6: Dry produce with a clean cloth or paper towel to further reduce bacteria that may be present.
en.washProduce_item_7: Remove the outermost leaves of a head of lettuce or cabbage.
en.thermometer_broken: Something is not right with this thermometer, should we proceed to use it?
en.thermometer_broken_correct: That's right, the thermometer's arrow didn't move when it was dipped into the glass. Good call!
en.thermometer_broken_wrong: Wrong! The thermometer's arrow didn't move when it was dipped into the glass.
en.dangerZoneTrivia1: A pot of beef stew has been placed in an ice-water bath to cool. After constant stirring, three hours have passed, and the temperature reads 70° F. Is the beef stew ready to be placed into the cooler?
en.dangerZoneTrivia10: No, the temperature didn't reach 70° F before two hours, it should be thrown out.
en.dangerZoneTrivia11: Yes, the stew has reached the proper temperature of 70° F, it should be ready to be placed in the cooler.
en.dangerZoneTrivia2: A tray of barbeque pork has been placed in the oven to be reheated. After 30 minutes, a server checks the internal temperature for 15 seconds. It reads 165° F.
en.dangerZoneTrivia20: The temperature looks good, it is ready to be served.
en.dangerZoneTrivia21: It still needs to be heated, put it back in the oven, and wait for another 30 minutes.
en.dangerZoneTrivia22: It is not safe to be served, throw it out.
en.dangerZoneTrivia3: A server has been sent to check on the temperature of a tray of barbeque chicken. After checking the internal temperature for 15 seconds, it reads 127° F. The tray has been out for at least an hour.
en.dangerZoneTrivia30: The tray needs to be heated up.
en.dangerZoneTrivia31: The temperature looks good, leave it alone.
en.dangerZoneTrivia4: Several broccoli salad trays being served have been out for more than an hour. A server decided to check the temperature of each tray. They all read 40° F.
en.dangerZoneTrivia40: The temperature looks good, leave it alone.
en.dangerZoneTrivia41: These shouldn't be served, replace it with a new batch.
en.dangerZoneTrivia42: It's too cold, they need to be heated up in a microwave.
en.dangerZoneTrivia5: A server was requested to check on the yogurt batch being served at the yogurt bar. After checking the temperature, it reads 53° F. Looking at the time it was brought out, it's been several hours.
en.dangerZoneTrivia50: This batch needs to be replaced.
en.dangerZoneTrivia51: The temperature is fine, leave it as is.
en.intro_1: Hello! I’m here to talk to you about the various safety procedures involved in food preparation.
en.intro_2: First off, let’s talk about personal hygiene!
en.intro_3: One of the most important steps before handling food is washing your hands.
en.intro_4: Remember to always wash your hands after using the restroom, before switching prep assignments, or before putting on disposable gloves.
en.washHands_1: Wash your hands with soap and warm water for a minimum of 20 seconds.
en.washHands_2: Do not handle food if you have a skin infection, or a cut on your hand.
